{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3162903,"name":"gartaud","username":"gartaud","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-12T19:57:55.793Z","cooked":"

Sometimes when programmers juggle between connecting to the Robot’s radio to test code changes and connecting to the school 's Wi-fi to pull and/or push code changes, they forget what they have last deployed to the robot. They can always redeploy, but that takes a few minutes, and when done repeatedly over an afternoon, can end up wasting quite a bit of time.

It would therefore be neat if one could easily tell by looking at the smartdash/shuffleboard when the code running on the robot was built and/or deployed (using the time reference from the laptop used to build and/or deploy being good enough).

Is there an easy way to do so? Thanks.

There is a good WPILib page about doing stuff like this: Including Git Data in Deploy — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

A “git log -1 --pretty=%B” would give us the last commit message which would be quite useful.

Yet this would not let us know if changes that have yet to be committed have been deployed.

Any suggestion on how we could address that?

I tried to solve that issue long ago and all the bizarre methods I came up with didn’t work right on the roboRIO or were too brittle for students to handle correctly every time (methods were easy but not student-proof).

I think now the jar file timestamp is correct (I can’t verify that since the roboRIO is still in the trailer) you could issue a Linux command in your program such as ls -lta and see file properties to print.

There are 7 settings to control what and where to put the time stamp.

Sorry, it’s stamping the SAVE not the DEPLOY but it could still be useful to put into each file and print in the static constructor. Maybe we can tap into the DEPLOY function.

In place of the git commands suggested in Including Git Data in Deploy — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation we use

commandLine 'git', 'describe', '--abbrev=8', '--dirty', '--always', '--exclude=*'

which produces a git hashcode with -dirty appended when you deploy something that has not be committed to git. We’ve found this idea very useful for several years and have routinely printed the githash when the robot code starts; this year we realized we should put it on the SmartDashboard, which has the added benefit that if you use DataLogManager to routinely save real-time logs you have the hashcode available for all the data you collect. Having this information available has saved our bacon a couple of times, so huge kudos the @Thad_House who helped us create the gradle code to support this and is probably behind the documentation cited above.

This is the solution I came up with a couple years back. I think it’s kinda cool, as it’s written in Java to collect the data and serialize it on deploy, then also runs the same class to display the data. Some of the suggestions here/on the WpiLib page might be good data to acquire with our framework. (now to add it to our robot, I forgot this season…)

RobotPy’s deploy mechanism gathers information about the deployment and copies it to a deploy.json and makes it accessible via robotpy-wpilib/deployinfo.py at main · robotpy/robotpy-wpilib · GitHub. Includes things like hostname, username, date/time of deploy, and git information such as branch name, HEAD commit, and whether the repo is dirty. All of this is printed to the console automatically when the robot code starts up, so users don’t have to do anything to get this.

Someone could add it to GradleRIO too.

Anything that records and displays the git commit id will pick up changes wherever they are made – the id is assigned at the time the commit is made (whether locally or on github) and remains the same for that commit regardless of movement to/from github. Given the commit id you can go to the exact code that was running (unless it was flagged as “dirty” which means your were running code that had never been committed. In that case the best you can do is go back to the commit from which the changes were started.)
It occurs to me that even this limitation could be overcome if the results of a git diff were put into the file that is put in the deploy/ folder. Something to think about.

Thanks for the instructions. I haven’t learned GitHub and didn’t setup our procedure to use it.

I think what you are saying as it relates to my team’s usage is if we change our procedure and commit before each deploy, we can get a unique identifier from your Java code that you posted. We are not online and normally have not been commiting except near the end of the day or at a few other important points.

We normally Pull (rebase) and Push immediately after committing but that’s because we went online. We don’t have to do that to take advantage of your commit id scheme. I’m not sure how all this works out when others are also making changes and the merges and any conflicts are managed.

The way my solution worked, it asked the local git repo what revision this code was based off of (commit id), and if there have been changes since that revision (dirty flag). If you did work offline, and haven’t synced up to the server yet, the commit ids will probably still be valid as commits ids are local first (unless you squash commits on branch merge).

I also grab the developers git name and when the software is built just in case too.

Again, other solutions might handle this situation more gracefully.
